properties.displayName: This node must be connected to an AI chain. Insert one
properties.name: notice
model
properties.description: The model which will generate the completion. Learn more.

properties.name: options
properties.description: Additional options to add

options.name: maxTokens
options.description: The maximum number of tokens to generate in the completion. Most models have a context length of 2048 tokens (except for the newest models, which support 32,768).

options.name: temperature
options.description: Controls randomness: Lowering results in less random completions. As the temperature approaches zero, the model will become deterministic and repetitive.

options.name: maxRetries
options.description: Maximum number of retries to attempt

options.name: topP
options.description: Controls diversity via nucleus sampling: 0.5 means half of all likelihood-weighted options are considered. We generally recommend altering this or temperature but not both.

options.name: safeMode
options.description: Whether to inject a safety prompt before all conversations

options.name: randomSeed
options.description: The seed to use for random sampling. If set, different calls will generate deterministic results.

properties.description: Name for and, optionally, path to the generated certificate file. /nsconfig/ssl/ is the default path.

properties.description: Format in which the certificate is stored on the appliance

options.name: Root-CA
options.description: You must specify the key file name. The generated Root-CA certificate can be used for signing end-user client or server certificates or to create Intermediate-CA certificates.

options.name: Intermediate-CA
options.description: Intermediate-CA certificate

options.name: Server
options.description: SSL server certificate used on SSL servers for end-to-end encryption

options.name: Client
options.description: End-user client certificate used for client authentication

properties.name: certificateRequestFileName
properties.description: Name for and, optionally, path to the certificate-signing request (CSR). /nsconfig/ssl/ is the default path.

properties.name: caCertificateFileName
properties.description: Name of the CA certificate file that issues and signs the Intermediate-CA certificate or the end-user client and server certificates

properties.name: caCertificateFileFormat
properties.description: Format of the CA certificate

properties.name: caPrivateKeyFileName
properties.description: Private key, associated with the CA certificate that is used to sign the Intermediate-CA certificate or the end-user client and server certificate. If the CA key file is password protected, the user is prompted to enter the pass phrase that was used to encrypt the key.

properties.name: caPrivateKeyFileFormat
properties.description: Format of the CA certificate

properties.name: privateKeyFileName
properties.description: Name for and, optionally, path to the private key. You can either use an existing RSA or DSA key that you own or create a new private key on the Netscaler ADC. This file is required only when creating a self-signed Root-CA certificate. The key file is stored in the /nsconfig/ssl directory by default.

properties.name: caSerialFileNumber
properties.description: Serial number file maintained for the CA certificate. This file contains the serial number of the next certificate to be issued or signed by the CA.

properties.name: privateKeyFormat
properties.description: Format in which the key is stored on the appliance

options.name: pempassphrase
options.description: Name for and, optionally, path to the private key. You can either use an existing RSA or DSA key that you own or create a new private key on the Netscaler ADC. This file is required only when creating a self-signed Root-CA certificate. The key file is stored in the /nsconfig/ssl directory by default.

options.name: pempassphrase
options.description: Name for and, optionally, path to the private key. You can either use an existing RSA or DSA key that you own or create a new private key on the Netscaler ADC. This file is required only when creating a self-signed Root-CA certificate. The key file is stored in the /nsconfig/ssl directory by default.

options.name: subjectaltname
options.description: Subject Alternative Name (SAN) is an extension to X.509 that allows various values to be associated with a security certificate using a subjectAltName field

options.name: days
options.description: Number of days for which the certificate will be valid, beginning with the time and day (system time) of creation

properties.name: certificateKeyPairName
properties.description: Name for the certificate and private-key pair

properties.name: certificateFileName
properties.description: Name of and, optionally, path to the X509 certificate file that is used to form the certificate-key pair. /nsconfig/ssl/ is the default path.

properties.name: privateKeyFileName
properties.description: Name of and, optionally, path to the X509 certificate file that is used to form the certificate-key pair. /nsconfig/ssl/ is the default path.

properties.name: certificateFormat
properties.description: Input format of the certificate and the private-key files. The three formats supported by the appliance are: PEM - Privacy Enhanced Mail DER - Distinguished Encoding Rule PFX - Personal Information Exchange.

properties.name: password
properties.description: Input format of the certificate and the private-key files. The three formats supported by the appliance are: PEM - Privacy Enhanced Mail DER - Distinguished Encoding Rule PFX - Personal Information Exchange.

properties.name: notifyExpiration
properties.description: Whether to alert when the certificate is about to expire

properties.name: notificationPeriod
properties.description: Time, in number of days, before certificate expiration, at which to generate an alert that the certificate is about to expire

properties.name: certificateBundle
properties.description: Whether to parse the certificate chain as a single file after linking the server certificate to its issuer's certificate within the file
